src.Plots module¶

src.Plots.plot_block_diffs(blocks, truths, title=None, active_label=1, fig_fname=None)[source]¶

Show percent of datapoints in each block where truth value is equal to active_label

Parameters:
  • blocks (np.array with shape (num_samples,)) – array of block or meta-values
  • truths (np.array with shape (num_samples,)) – array of truth labels / ground truth data
  • title (str) – (Default: “”) Super plot title
  • active_label – (Default: 1) truth_value being counted from truths
  • fig_fname (str) – (Default: None) If given value, saves as <fig_fname>.png
src.Plots.plot_colormesh(x, xlabel='', ylabel='Density', yticks=None, title='', fig_fname=None)[source]¶

2D colormesh (e.g. rastor plot)

Parameters:
  • x (numpy.array) – 2D array of data with shape (num_samples, num_features)
  • xlabel (str) – (Default: Time) label to use on x-axis
  • ylabel (str) – (Default: Amplitude) label to use on y-axis
  • yticks (list of str) – (Default: None) ticks to use to label individual y spots
  • title (str) – (Default: “”) Super plot title
  • fig_fname (str) – (Default: None) If given value, saves as <fig_fname>.png
src.Plots.plot_model_history(history, metric='loss', fig_fname=None, xlabel='Epoch', ylabel='Metric', title='')[source]¶

Plots desired metric over course of training

Parameters:
  • history (tensorflow.keras.Sequential.fit) – fitted model (TF keras)
  • metric (str {'loss', 'accuracy'}) – metric which will be plotted over epochs
  • fig_fname (str) – (Default: None) If given value, saves as <fig_fname>.png
  • xlabel (str) – (Default: Time) label to use on x-axis
  • ylabel (str) – (Default: Amplitude) label to use on y-axis
  • title (str) – (Default: “”) Super plot title
src.Plots.plot_outcome_hist(x, y, n_bins=20, density=True, xlabel='', ylabel='Density', title='', fig_fname=None)[source]¶

Plot two overlaid histograms, one group with outcome=0, one with outcome=1

Parameters:
  • x (np.array with shape (num_samples,)) – 1D array of data
  • y (np.array with shape (num_samples,)) – 1D array of corresponding outcomes
  • n_bins (int) – number of bins to use
  • density (bool) – (Default: True) Whether to use a density histogram or not
  • xlabel (str) – (Default: Time) label to use on x-axis
  • ylabel (str) – (Default: Amplitude) label to use on y-axis
  • title (str) – (Default: “”) Super plot title
  • fig_fname (str) – (Default: None) If given value, saves as <fig_fname>.png
src.Plots.plot_xy_line(x, y, xlabel='Time', ylabel='Amplitude', logy=False, share=False, title=None, fig_fname=None, labels=None, plot_axis=False)[source]¶

Inspect a handful of datapoints on a plot of data vs. features

Parameters:
  • x (np.array with shape (num_features,)) – values along x-axis
  • y (np.array with shape (num_samples, num_features)) – values or set of values along y-axis
  • xlabel (str) – (Default: Time) label to use on x-axis
  • ylabel (str) – (Default: Amplitude) label to use on y-axis
  • logy (bool) – (Default: False) if True, uses semilogy
  • share (bool) – (Default: True) if True, doesn’t use subplots
  • title (str) – (Default: “”) Super plot title
  • fig_fname (str) – (Default: None) If given value, saves as <fig_fname>.png
  • labels (list or np.array with shape / len (num_samples,)) – (Default: None) If given, label for each sample in y
src.Plots.roc_curve(preds, truths, fig_fname=None)[source]¶

Plot ROC curve for given predictions and truth array

Parameters:
  • preds (list) – list of numpy.array objects, each with a pack of predictions
  • truths (numpy.array) – list of truth (outcome) values of type binary classification
  • fig_fname (str) – (Default: None) If given value, saves as <fig_fname>.png

src.Statistics module¶

src.Statistics.icc(Y, icc_type='ICC(3, k)')[source]¶

Calculate intraclass correlation coefficient

ICC Formulas are based on: Shrout, P. E., & Fleiss, J. L. (1979). Intraclass correlations: uses in assessing rater reliability. Psychological bulletin, 86(2), 420. icc1: x_ij = mu + beta_j + w_ij icc2/3: x_ij = mu + alpha_i + beta_j + (ab)_ij + epsilon_ij Code modifed from nipype algorithms.icc https://github.com/nipy/nipype/blob/master/nipype/algorithms/icc.py

Parameters:
  • Y (numpy.array) – N x X matrix (rows = raters, columns = measurements)
  • icc_type (str) – type of ICC to calculate, one of: {ICC(2,1), ICC(2, k), ICC(3, 1), ICC(3, k)}
Returns:

ICC (numpy.array) intraclass correlation coefficient
src.Statistics.ping_icc(dX, icc_type='ICC1')[source]¶

Computes the intraclass correlation coefficient via Pingouin of a given 2 equally-sized arrays. The expectation at build is that they are linear time-series.

Parameters:
  • dX (list of TimeSeries.TimeSeries) – list of TimeSeries.TimeSeries objects for which the icc will be calculated
  • icc_type (str) – one of {ICC1, ICC2, ICC3, ICC1k, ICC2k, ICC3k}
src.Statistics.unordered_pearson(Y)[source]¶

The assessment of correlation via the familiar Pearson product-moment procedure applies only to those situations where one particular member of a bivariate pair of measures unequivocally belongs to the X variable and the other unequivocally belongs to the Y variable.

When it is entirely arbitrary which of the items within the pair is listed first and which is listed second.

Parameters:Y (numpy.array) – N x X matrix (rows = raters, columns = measurements)

src.TimeSeries module¶

class src.TimeSeries.TimeSeries(signal, time=None, sampleRate=1024, meta={}, unit='s')[source]¶

Bases: object

Object which stores time-series data and offers various signal-related manipulations

Parameters:
  • signal (numpy.array) – Time-series data of shape (timepoints,)
  • time (numpy.array) – (Default: None) If None, defaults to np.arange(len(signal)), else array of shape (timepoints,)
  • sampleRate (int) – (Default: 1024) frequency (in Hz) at which data was collected
center(difference=1)[source]¶

Substracts ‘difference’ from signal

Parameters:difference (int, float) – amount substracted from signal
fix_nan(val='interpol')[source]¶

Helper to fill occurances of NaNs in self.signal and self.time First trims tails, then retro-fills any remaining middle-wise

Parameters:val (str, float, int) – (Default: ‘interpol’) if not ‘interpol’, float or int which will replace NaNs
get_moving_average(x, w=10, mode='same')[source]¶

Builds moving average via convolution

Parameters:
  • x (numpy.array) – data with shape (n_timepoints,) or (n_samples,)
  • w (int) – (Default: 5) length of window over which averages are made
lag_correct()[source]¶

During recording, skipped frames can add up to significant differences in the number of samples collected between subjects, even though the start / stop time are correct, and the sample rate generally holds true.

This method regularizes time axis values along an ARTIFICIAL new axis, such that they are equally spaced apart.

resample(sample_rate=1, new_unit=None)[source]¶

Resamples self.signal and self.time with numpy (tail padding)

Parameters:
  • sample_rate (float) – (default 1) new sample rate (in Hz) to which data are resampled
  • new_unit (str) – (default None) if not None, reassigns self.unit
round_res(n=5, vmin=0, vmax=2)[source]¶

This method is a form of “chunking” a signal, such that a “smooth” signal becomes piece-wise in appearance, with every value in the original signal being rounded to one of n possible values. Effectively, it lowers the amplitudinal resolution of a signal to n.

Parameters:
  • n (int) – (Default: 5) number of possible values, i.e. bins
  • vmin (int, float) – (Default: 0) the virtual minimum of the original signal
  • vmax (int, float) – (Default: 2) the virtual maximum of the original signal
savgol_filter(w=13, poly_order=3)[source]¶

Sets self.signal to the savgol-filtered (smoothed) timeseries

Parameters:
  • w (int) – (Default: 13) window length (in samples)
  • poly_order (int) – (Default: 3) polynomial order of the filter
scale(ylim=(-1, 1))[source]¶

Linearly scales max and min values of the signal to the respective lower and upper bounds of ylim

Parameters:ylim (tuple of type int or float) – lower and upper bound of scale
set_PSD(x, window='boxcar')[source]¶

Estimate power spectral density using a periodogram

Parameters:window (str) – (Default: boxcar) Desired window to use. If window is a string or tuple, it is passed to get_window to generate the window values, which are DFT-even by default. See get_window for a list of windows and required parameters. If window is array_like it will be used directly as the window and its length must be nperseg.
set_n_peaks(n=3, bin_ranges=None)[source]¶

Counts number of peaks (timepoints with signal in certain amplitudinal range) found in self.signal within n possible bins.

Parameters:
  • n (int) – (Default: 3) number of amplitude bins
  • bin_ranges (length n list of tuples) – (None) if none, arbitrarily defines bins based off range found in signal. If int / float, builds list of ranges based off this as max. If list, defines custom bin ranges.
standardize()[source]¶

Normalizes rating (i.e. subtract mean) and scale variance to 1
